oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Portrait of Alfred Leland Crabb, undated
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
An elderly Alfred Leland Crabb, balding, with grey hair and glasses. He is wearing a jacket, vest, white shirt, and rust colored tie. Born in Kentucky in 1884, author, educator, and historian Alfred Leland Crabb was educated at Bethel College, Peabody College, University of Chicago, and Columbia University. He married Bertha Gardner in 1911. Crabb became editor of the Peabody Journal of Education in 1932, a position he continued to hold until 1970 after retiring from his teaching career at Peabody in 1949. Crabb is most famous for his historical novels. Oil on canvas, on display in the Nashville Room on the Nashville Public Library's second floor.
The library's portraits were photographed as part of the National Society of The Colonial Dames of America in Tennessee's Tennessee Portrait Project (http://www.tnportraits.org/index.htm).
